model_response: The study is designed as a phase 1 open-label, two-arm study. The study participants will be randomized in either the drug combination group or the control group. Participants assigned to the drug combination group will receive Ziv-aflibercept plus Cemiplimab. Participants assigned to the control group will receive Ziv-Aflibercept alone or placebo (which is an inactive substance that is similar to Cemiplimab) plus Cemiplimab in the same dose.

The combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept is an experimental treatment, and there is no prior experience with treating metastatic uveal melanoma using these two agents in combination. Therefore, in the absence of any data on the best dosing schedule of these agents, the schedule chosen is based on the pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) characteristics of the individual Ziv-Aflibercept and Cemiplimab drugs. PK and PD data from single-agent studies with Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept are being evaluated to determine the optimal dosing schedule for each drug. This combination trial design was chosen based on the PK and PD profiles of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept when administered individually. Studies showed that Cemiplimab PK is not impacted when it is administered along with other concomitant anticancer agents, and its maximum serum concentrations are not affected by other coadministered drugs. Therefore, the schedule of Cemiplimab being given every 3 weeks was deemed suitable. Studies also showed that when Ziv-Aflibercept is given along with other agents, its Cmax (the maximum plasma concentration that is achieved during the first dosing interval for a drug) is approximately two-fold higher than when Ziv-Aflibercept is given alone. Therefore, the schedule of Ziv-Aflibercept being given every 2 weeks was deemed suitable.

As with any experimental treatment, the combination therapy used in this study may cause adverse effects in some participants. However, the goal of the study is to determine the safety and efficacy of the treatment, so the potential benefits outweigh the risks. The clinical trial also involves regular monitoring of participants to ensure the safety of the treatment and identify any potential side effects. The reasoning behind the design of the experimental arm is to evaluate the short-term clinical effectiveness of Ghrelin in patients with acute stroke. The study arm comprises two phases, as per the protocol outlined in the trial: the acute phase from hospital admission until 5 days after hospitalization and the post-acute phase from 6 days to 90 days after hospitalization. In the acute phase, administration of Ghrelin is designed to promote early neurological restoration and functional recovery. The daily frequency and dosage of Ghrelin were selected by referring to previous clinical trials and pharmacological studies. The length of treatment and follow-up period were set by considering the timeframe for spontaneous neurological recovery and the longest period where the potential effects from Ghrelin could be assessed in the post-acute phase.

The control group will be labeled as "Control: Standard care". This group will consist of patients who receive standard care, which will differ depending on their admission status. Stroke patients who are admitted within six hours of onset will receive standard care with intravenous alteplase. Stroke patients who are presented to the ED after six hours will receive standard care with EVT if indicated for their condition.

The intervention/treatment for the control group will be standard care for stroke, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated. The standard treatment does not include Ghrelin or any other hormone-based or nutritional intervention.

The control group, who will receive standard care for the treatment of stroke, will serve as a benchmark to compare the efficacy and safety of Ghrelin in the experimental group. This will allow us to assess whether the addition of Ghrelin treatment can improve the outcomes of stroke patients undergoing endovascular thrombectomy (EVT).

Patients randomized to Group 1 (DCCV + PVI) will undergo general anesthesia with either a femoral or a tibial access, followed by DC cardioversion and pulmonary vein isolation (PVI: circumferential ablation lines at antral and left anterior of each vein) using a three-dimensional electroanatomical mapping system. During the procedure, heparin will be administered targeting a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) at 60–80 seconds and maintaining the electrode catheter in the pulmonary veins with the patient on continuous electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring. For the narrow implants, the initial surgical phase of the implant placement will follow the regular protocol, with the placement of standard bone level Rex three-piece implants with an insertion torque above 35 Ncm. I think we could design another study arm focusing on radioligand therapy (RLT). We could call it "Concurrent treatment (RLT/EBRT): Radioligand Therapy + External Beam Radiotherapy". This arm would involve the injection of RLT and subsequent external beam radiotherapy to deliver radiation doses. The goal would be to determine if this concurrent radioligand and radiation therapy would enhance antitumor effects by damaging tumor glands directly with radiation and at the same time increasing radiation dose by the action of RLT. The advantage of treating at an earlier stage is the reduced likelihood of encountering barriers to the treatment of cancer such as inflammation or scar tissue formation, which may lead to a better response to treatment. This arm would help us compare and identify potential improvements that may result from the addition of radioligand therapy. Let me know if you have any further requirements or specifications for this study arm.

In the second study arm, patients will receive the same treatment as the first arm (external beam radiotherapy followed by 177Lu-rhPSMA-10 radioligand therapy) plus additional radiotherapy in the form of 177Lu-PSMA-617 radioligand therapy (EBRT, 177Lu-rhPSMA-10, and 177Lu-PSMA-617). As the second arm will build upon the previous trial arm, we can refer to this arm as "Early Dual β "-EBRT, 177Lu-rhPSMA-10, and 177Lu-PSMA-617. The rationale for this arm is to investigate the potential increase in therapeutic efficacy with the addition of 177Lu-PSMA-617 radioligand therapy. Additionally, the use of biospecimen collection and functional imaging allows for monitoring of treatment response and side effects.

Yes, that is correct! I would recommend a slightly modified exclusion criterion: patients should not have any contraindications to radiotherapy (including active inflammatory bowel disease or prior pelvic radiotherapy or prior radioligand therapy) or any risk factors for lum-177PSMA therapy (baseline >= grade 2 myelosuppression, renal insufficiency or xerostomia), definitive findings of systemic metastasis, unacceptable medical or radiation safety risk, unmanageable urinary tract obstruction or hydronephrosis or severe acute co-morbidities. Each heating pad size will cover a maximum of an 8 cm×8 cm area of the hands and feet. The temperature will be regulated within the range of 37°C to 38°C. Each participant will receive hot compress packs approximately 15 minutes before the infusion and for 30 minutes following the completion of the infusion. The main aim of using hot compresses is to prevent vasospasms of the hands or feet, and this is also commonly used as a nursing care after surgery. The warm temperature can increase blood flow and reduce the possibility of vasospasms, and this was observed by a study published in the International Nursing Journal, which found that using hot compress therapy and gentle massages could help prevent vasospasms in the patient's extremities that were likely to occur after surgery . Cold compress treatment is an effective nursing care procedure used in postoperative recovery and for the treatment of inflammatory diseases in medical care . Based on this, the use of cold compresses is expected to significantly reduce pain in this study.

The hot compressing group will receive interventions of temperature control within the range of 37-38 °C. In the Eun et al. study, the hot compresses were conducted once a week for 8 consecutive weeks and only included one intervention during the chemotherapy period. On the other hand, our study involves hot compresses conducted twice a week for 20 minutes, along with two applications at the beginning and end of the Oxaliplatin infusion.

In the cold compressing group, patients will receive cold compress interventions on their hands and feet. The temperature control will be maintained within the range of 12-18 degrees Celsius. model_response: Phase 4 of a clinical trial is known as the evaluation or post-marketing phase. This phase is not a formal requirement for marketing approval, but it is conducted voluntarily and can last for many years. It involves ongoing monitoring of the drug's safety and effectiveness in actual patients, who may have varying characteristics from those studied in Phase 3 trials. The phase is also known as the drug utilization assessment phase, as it allows the assessment of how a drug is used in the real-world setting. Phase 4 trials are performed after a drug has been approved and marketed for use, and there is substantial evidence indicating that many drugs are evaluated differently under real-world conditions compared to clinical trial settings.

model_response: Thank you for the inclusion and exclusion criteria. In terms of the study type for this trial, it sounds like the study falls under a randomized controlled trial (RCT). RCTs are characterized by their prospective design, which involves randomly assigning research participants to one of two (or sometimes more) interventions to systematically test the effects of each intervention compared to the others. RCTs provide the strongest evidence for the effectiveness of an intervention, but the study design also has strict criteria for inclusion. These criteria ensure that the study group and control group are similar enough to be considered comparable and that any differences that arise are directly related to the intervention.
